III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109 Program Statement
Section
Description (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care,
safety, and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation A former staff inappropriately touched a youth's inner thigh.
Investigation On 6/13/23 I spoke to Complainant 1. No additional information
was provided.
Interviews at the facility on 6/14/23 with DHHS Worker 1 and
Law Enforcement:
Youth A reported during the interview that Staff 1 has tickled her
all over and down by her pants, lower belly and inner thigh, genital
area. Youth A reported Staff 1 doesn’t tickle anyone else. Youth A
reported she did not tell anyone about it. Youth A reported that
Staff 1 also ticked Youth B, but was told to stop. Staff 1 then
discontinued tickling Youth B.
Youth B reported during the interview that staff tickle the youth.
Youth B reported that staff have tickled her feet, belly, chest,
behind the knees and neck. Youth B reported that staff do hug as
well.
Youth C reported during the interview that staff do tickle the youth.
Youth C reported she has not been tickled by Staff 1.
Administrator 1 reported during the interview that she has not had
issues in the past with Staff 1 tickling youth inappropriately.
On 7/13/23 the following phone interviews were done:
2

Supervisor 1 reported that they don’t have a policy that states the
staff cannot tickle the youth. Supervisor 1 was unsure if tickling
was ok and stated she would have to look up policies to see.
Supervisor 1 reported there would not be tickling on the bed
though. Supervisor 1 reported she has never had any youth tell
her that staff were tickling them, and they did not want staff to do
so. Supervisor 1 reported that Staff 1 has been told to stop
rubbing a child’s back once. Supervisor 1 reported she had
stopped and then started again later. Supervisor 1 reported that
she did have to repeat herself to Staff 1 to follow various
expectations. Supervisor 1 reported she would show
understanding but then go back to doing the previous activity
again. Supervisor 1 reported that Staff 1 would have “power
struggles” with administration at times. Supervisor1 reported she
has never seen or heard about Staff 1 touching a youth
inappropriately.
Staff 2 reported staff are allowed to use Haptic Touch. Staff 2
described this as side hugs, hand holding, and back rubs. Staff 2
reported staff have to use their discernment to recognize when to
touch and when not to based on the youth’s background. Staff 2
reported tickling is allowed. Staff 2 reported they have had several
meetings and trainings pertaining to haptic touch. Staff 2 reported
she never noticed any inappropriate touching done by Staff 1.
Staff 2 reported she never saw Staff 1 tickling a youth. Staff 1
reported that it would be out of character for Youth A not to be
vocal if someone touched her in a way she didn’t like. Staff 2
reported she might be quiet if it was bullying from other youth
though. Staff 2 reported that Staff 1 was good at being at
trainings.
Interview 7/13/23 with DHHS Worker 1:
Staff 1 did bring a support person into the interview. It was clear
that Staff 1 would need some accommodations due to cognitive
understanding. DHHS Worker 1 and I rephrased questions and
broke down words for better understanding. Staff 1 reported the
agency encouraged physical touch with the youth. Staff 1 reported
they could give high fives, play tag, and tickling. Staff 1 reported
one time she was asked to stop tickling a youth and she did listen.
(This was not Youth A). Staff 1 reported she has not touched
anyone in the genital area while tickling on accident or purpose.
The following documents were reviewed:
3

Haptic Support and Physical Touch Policy:
…children need positive haptic support and loving guidance to
understand positive touch and healthy affection…trauma informed
guidelines…govern physical touch between staff and residents.
• No laying with a resident
• No resident heads resting in laps
• No “spread eagle” positioning on a staffs lap, or anywhere
else on a person
• No piggy back rides
• No full front hugs
The policy does not specify that tickling is disallowed.
Youth A safety plan:
Identified strengths-based strategies that have helped you de-
escalate in the past:
• Haptics
I reviewed Staff 1’s training and policy compliance meetings with
administration. Staff 1 was compliant with training requirements.
Staff 1 had one “Policy Compliance Meeting” where she had a
discussion on respecting youth’s boundaries. Staff had refused to
comply when told to respect boundaries.
Analysis There is no evidence to validate the allegations. The agency
allows tickling of youth by staff. Staff are to use discernment when
tickling or touching a youth in a nurturing way. The agency policy
does not specify that tickling is not allowed. There were no
witnesses to collaborate an inappropriate touching from Staff 1
towards Youth A. Should additional information become available
this investigation will be re-opened.
Another Department of the state had no findings.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
4

Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
